  "article_text": [
    "in this work we study the asymptotic behavior of two analytic functions @xmath2 and @xmath3 generated by a sequence of moments @xmath4 , where @xmath5 is an analytic function in the angle @xmath6 with @xmath7 and @xmath8 .",
    "the function @xmath9 satisfies certain regularity properties , which we will list shortly . here",
    ", we will only mention that @xmath10 is a fastly growing sequence of positive numbers ( so that @xmath11 ) , and that , for some @xmath12 , @xmath13 this allows us to define the functions @xmath14 where @xmath15 is a union of two rays traversed is such a way that @xmath16 increases along @xmath17 ( see figure 1 ) , and @xmath18    ]    the function @xmath2 is analytic on the riemann surface of @xmath19 ( that is , the function @xmath20 is entire ) , while the function @xmath3 is an entire one .    the assumptions on the function @xmath9 , which we will impose shortly , will allow us , moving the integration contour , represent the function @xmath21 for @xmath22 as the inverse mellin transform of @xmath9 : @xmath23 where the integral does not depend on the choice of @xmath24 .",
    "then , by the inversion formula for the mellin transform , @xmath2 solves the moment problem @xmath25    the functions @xmath2 and @xmath3 naturally appear in various classical problems of analysis , for instance , in the borel - type moment summation of divergent series @xcite and in studying in convergence of certain interpolation problems for entire functions @xcite .",
    "it also worth mentioning that beurling  @xcite singled out a class of functions @xmath9 for which the function @xmath2 is positive on the positive half - line ( see section  1.7 and appendix  b ) .",
    "then , our theorem  1 gives explicit asymptotics of solutions to a large class of determinate stieltjes moment problem .",
    "our interest originated in beurling s approach to the problems of description of the taylor coefficients and of summation of the divergent taylor series in various classes of smooth functions @xcite",
    ".    it could be that the results presented here are known to experts .",
    "on the other hand , we were unable to locate them in the literature and we believe that they are of certain interest .    at last , we note that juxtaposing the right - hand sides of and , we may expect some match between the growth of @xmath3 and the decay of @xmath2 on the positive half - line and nearby . in the prototype case when @xmath9 is euler s gamma  function , @xmath26 , @xmath27 , @xmath28 , and this match is prefect .      from now on",
    ", we will assume that the function @xmath9 is analytic and non - vanishing in the angle @xmath6 with @xmath7 and @xmath8 , and is positive on @xmath29 .",
    "we put @xmath30    we call the function @xmath9 _ admissible _ , if the function @xmath31 is positive and bounded on @xmath32 , and satisfies the following conditions :    * @xmath33 , * @xmath34 as @xmath35 , * for @xmath36 , @xmath35 , one has @xmath37 , uniformly in any angle @xmath38 .",
    "condition ( a ) means that the function @xmath39 is unbounded .",
    "condition ( b ) says that the function @xmath31 is slowly varying .",
    "everywhere below , _ we always assume that the function @xmath9 is admissible_.    it is not difficult to see that conditions ( b ) and ( c ) yield that , for @xmath40 , @xmath35 ,    * @xmath41 , * @xmath42 ,    also uniformly in any angle @xmath43 .    indeed , condition ( d ) follows from ( c ) by integration , while ( e ) follows from ( c ) and ( b ) due to the analyticity of @xmath31 .    below , in sections  1.5 and 1.6 , we will give several examples and constructions of admissible functions @xmath9 .",
    "it is clear , at least intuitively , that the asymptotic behavior of the functions @xmath44 and @xmath45 for large @xmath46 should be determined by the saddle - point of the function @xmath47 , that is by the equation @xmath48 which we will call _ the saddle - point equation_.    for @xmath49 and @xmath50 , put @xmath51 and let @xmath52 note that for @xmath53 and @xmath54 sufficiently large , by ( b),(c ) and ( e ) , we have @xmath55 thus , for @xmath56 , @xmath57 , @xmath58 provided that @xmath59 is large enough . therefore , for @xmath59 sufficiently large , the function @xmath60 , that is , the lhs of the saddle - point equation , is a univalent function in @xmath61 . from here on , we assume that this is the case .",

    "note that it is not difficult to drop assumption   in theorem  [ theoreme ] at the expense of a more complicated conclusion .",
    "we shall not do this here .",
    "one of the reasons is that we are mainly interested in the case when @xmath68 as @xmath79 .",
    "we also note that the asymptotics given in theorems  [ theoreme ] and  [ theoremk ] are known in the case when there exists a positive limit @xmath80 cf .",
    "@xcite . in this case",
    ", @xmath3 is an entire function of order @xmath81 .",
    "the logarithmic case @xmath82 is also classical and goes back to lindelf .",
    "@xmath83 @xmath84 . in this case",

    "we note that the entire function @xmath3 has nearly maximal growth in the curvilinear strip @xmath91 , while the analytic function @xmath2 has nearly fastest decay in @xmath91 , and that , for sufficiently large @xmath92 , @xmath93 where @xmath94    [ [ section ] ]    the observation we have just made is quite general , for any curvilinear semistrip @xmath95 which is bounded by two sufficiently regularly varying curves @xmath96 , one can find a function @xmath9 , satisfying our regularity conditions ( a ) , ( b ) and ( c ) , so that the entire function @xmath3 will have nearly maximal growth in @xmath95 , while the analytic function @xmath2 will have nearly fastest decay in @xmath95 .",
    "we shall not pursue that matter here .",

    "the following simple rules allow one to construct new admissible functions form the given ones :    [ [ section-4 ] ]    if @xmath9 is admissible and @xmath102 , then the function @xmath107 is also admissible .",
    "[ [ section-5 ] ]    if @xmath108 and @xmath109 are admissible , then @xmath110 is always admissible , while @xmath111 is admissible provided that @xmath112 on @xmath113 and that the function @xmath114 is non - decreasing and unbounded .",
    "[ [ section-6 ] ]    if @xmath115 is admissible , then the function @xmath116 is admissible as well .",
    "it is not difficult to construct admissible functions with prescribed asymptotic behavior on the positive ray .",

    "this justifies rotation of the integration contour .",
    "the function @xmath421 remains bounded for @xmath422 $ ] and @xmath423 . since the main term of the asymptotics comes from the integration over @xmath424 and grows very fast , we may discard the integration over the segment @xmath425 $ ] and estimate only the integral over @xmath424 .",
    "the estimates we need are practically identical to the ones from  [ subsubsect:3.3.3 ] .",

    "following beurling , we say that a function @xmath9 is _ of positive type _ if it can be represented in the form @xmath551 with real constants @xmath552 and @xmath553 , and with a non - decreasing function @xmath554 such that @xmath555      note that the functions @xmath556 and @xmath557 , @xmath84 , @xmath24 and sufficiently big , are of positive type ( here , as before , @xmath99 is the @xmath100th iterate of the logarithmic function ) . in the first case",

    "hence , by the schwarz reflection principle , its jump on the negative ray is purely imaginary",
    ". then , it is not difficult to see that @xmath569 is positive , provided that the constant @xmath253 is big .            * theorem ( beurling ) . *",
    "_ every function @xmath9 of positive type is mellin - positive definite , that is , represented by an absolutely convergent stieltjes integral @xmath570 with a non  decreasing function @xmath571 on @xmath515 . _",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we study the asymptotic behaviour of the entire function @xmath0 and the analytic function @xmath1 which naturally appear in various classical problems of analysis . </S>"
